In 1997, the load on the instrument platform was increased by 300 tonnes by the addition of the Gregorian dome, which not only increased the telescopes abilities, but also significantly increased the stress in old, degraded cables.It was recognised that the cables were degrading in the corrosive environment, and to that end they were covered in a layer of paint to seal them off from the air, and treated, dry air was blown continuously through the cable cores by fans. This system was not maintained however, and by 2007 the circulation fans were not running. The cable end sockets were also found to be faulty, with multiple flaws detected in the zinc plug material during a 2011 inspection.Individual wire breakages were common, and the operators got used to hearing them during operation. With every breakage, the cable lost 1/160 of its overall strength, and regular breakages should have stopped operation.In hindsight it’s easy to say that they should have done things differently. The obvious one would have been a replacement of the original dry cables with marine grade ones when the major rebuild in 1997 was undertaken. With the extra loading of the new heavy equipment it would seem reasonable to renew them, and upgrade to a higher safety factor. If done so the telescope could still be operating for decades to come, but the curse of all operations like this, money (or the lack of it), meant that they were not able to do what was needed from an engineering viewpoint.When it got to the point where one of the support cables had failed, it was too late to do anything as all the safety factor had been used up, and the structure was too fragile for anybody to work on.
